exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The afternoon light was fading as Juan made his way through the corridors of the Palace of Blachernae toward the apartments where Lucia and Catalina had been settled. Byzantine servants bowed as he passed, their faces carefully blank. He had almost reached his chambers when he noticed the first sign. A knot of men in the courtyard below—visible through a window overlooking the interior gardens. Dark robes. The Patriarch's household, by their dress. They moved with purpose toward the private wing of the palace, led by a younger priest who walked quickly, a sealed letter clutched in his hand. The Patriarch had left the first council in anger. Now his messengers were returning to the palace.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Evening. Lucia noticed his distraction at dinner. Catalina played with a wooden horse that some Byzantine servant had found for her, making it gallop across the table while her nursemaid tried to interest her in food. Before Juan could answer, a commotion in the corridor outside. Raised voices—Greek, too fast for Juan to follow, but the tone was unmistakable. Argument. Then silence, and the sound of boots moving away quickly. A servant entered moments later with wine. His hands trembled slightly as he poured.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Night. Juan could not sleep. He stood at the window of their chambers, looking out over the city. Constantinople spread below him—dark shapes of domes and towers, scattered lights, the distant gleam of the Golden Horn under a half-moon. Movement caught his eye. A procession of torches moving through the streets below the palace walls. Twelve, perhaps fifteen men on horseback, riding toward the Blachernae gate. The lead rider carried a banner Juan could not make out in the darkness, but the size of the escort spoke of wealth. Of importance. The hoofbeats faded. Somewhere in the palace, a door slammed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Before Dawn. Juan had finally drifted into restless sleep when a sound woke him—voices in the corridor, hushed but urgent. He rose quietly, not waking Lucia, and moved to the door. Through the gap, he could see two Byzantine servants speaking with one of his own men—a Castilian sergeant who had been posted as guard. The sergeant's face was troubled.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Morning. The summons to council came late—nearly midday, when Juan had expected to be called at dawn. The messenger who brought it was not the same young functionary who had attended them before. This one was older, his face carved from stone, his bow precisely correct and entirely without warmth. Outside the council chamber, two men stood waiting. Juan recognized neither, but their dress marked them as nobility. They studied him as he approached, murmured something to each other in Greek, and did not bow. The doors opened.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The chamber had been rearranged. The intimate circle of yesterday was gone. Now a long table dominated the room, with the Emperor seated at its head—and the Emperor was not alone. Father Gennadios sat to his left, his face grave and unreadable. Kantakouzenos to his right, arms crossed, expression troubled. But beyond them— Patriarch Joseph II occupied a seat of honor, his ancient frame draped in vestments of gold and black. His sharp eyes fixed on Juan the moment he entered. And at the far end of the table, relaxed, well-dressed, watching with the faint smile of a man who has won a hand at cards— Loukas Notaras. The Megas Doux inclined his head slightly.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: King of Castile. How good of you to join us.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor's face was exhausted, hollow. He did not meet Juan's eyes.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I think someone has been busy. How are you two? I thought you had wanted to leave the planning council. I am glad you have changed your mind and have decided to join the planning session again. May I ask what has changed your mind?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch's ancient face remained impassive, but something flickered in those sharp eyes—a flicker of satisfaction, quickly buried.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Planning. Yes. We have heard much of your... planning. It seemed prudent that those who speak for the faith of this city should be present when its future is discussed. The Emperor, in his wisdom, agreed.

exchanges.speaker: loukas_notaras
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile, I confess I departed hastily yesterday. The hour was late. Tempers were... warm. But I have had time to reflect. And I realized that a man of my position—with certain resources, certain responsibilities to this city—should not absent himself from conversations of such importance. I am here to help. As I have always helped Constantinople in her hour of need. His Imperial Majesty has graciously welcomed my counsel. And the Patriarch's, of course. We are all united in our desire to see the city defended.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor still had not spoken. His hands rested flat on the table, very still. Father Gennadios caught Juan's eye briefly. The priest's expression was guarded, but something in it spoke of warning. Of apology, perhaps. Kantakouzenos sat like a stone, his scarred face revealing nothing.

encounters.recap: Overnight, the Byzantine opposition mobilized against Juan's proposals. The Patriarch and Loukas Notaras formed a coalition, bringing sixty armed men to the palace and pressuring Emperor John. When the council reconvened, Juan faced a completely transformed political situation with his former allies now outnumbered and intimidated.

exchanges.text: Well great! Let me catch you up to speed. We have made great progress yesterday to plan for victory of the empire against the muslim incursion and restore it's old glory. Central in the planning has been that we are not making demands, but we rather are presenting a choice. A choice that will allow the empire to drive the muslims from the lands and unite with our christian brothers of the latin tradition. Like I told you yesterday, the religeous aspects will remain as they are. There are latin and orthodox traditions and they will exist in peace beside one another. Like brothers and sisters living in peace together. A great way to improve the population, trade and alliances of the city will be to let latins own and live in the city itself. This will boost the revenue and trade, but also will increase the population greatly. The city needs this economic impulse. Taxes will be extracted by crown appointed servants and will flow directy to the treasury. We re-institute the ancient noble obligation that all nobles must fight under the crown when called. exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch did not respond immediately. He sat in silence, letting Juan's words settle over the room like dust after a collapse. Then, slowly, he rose. He was ancient—eighty years or more, his frame bent with age, his hands trembling slightly where they gripped the edge of the table. But his voice, when it came, carried the weight of centuries.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Four hundred years. Four hundred years since Rome and Constantinople divided. Four hundred years since the Pope claimed supremacy over all Christendom and we refused to kneel. Four hundred years of our fathers and their fathers holding fast to the true faith, the unchanged faith, the faith delivered once to the saints.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He moved slowly around the table, his vestments rustling.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: And in all that time, what has Rome offered us? Crusades. The first, the second, the third—Latin armies marching east, and somehow never arriving in time to save us. Always too late. Always too busy with their own quarrels. Until the fourth.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The word hung in the air.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: The Fourth Crusade. Twelve hundred and four. The year our Christian brothers came to save us. They came with crosses on their shields. They came singing hymns. And then they burned Constantinople for three days. They raped our women in the Hagia Sophia. They melted down the treasures of a thousand years to make coins. They placed a prostitute on the Patriarch's throne and made her sing obscene songs.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios had gone pale. He stared at the table.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Two hundred and thirty years ago. There are men in this city whose grandfathers remember. Whose great-grandfathers saw the smoke, smelled the burning. We do not forget. And now another Latin king comes. With crosses on his shields. Singing hymns. Offering salvation. And what does he ask in return? Only everything. Our laws. Our trade. Our property. Our crown. He promises our faith will be respected—as the Fourth Crusade promised. He says Latins and Greeks will live as brothers—as they lived as brothers when Latin soldiers used our icons for firewood. You speak of choice, King of Castile. But what choice is this? Accept Latin rule or die? This is not choice. This is the same demand Rome has made for four hundred years, dressed in sweeter words.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turned to the Emperor, and his voice softened—but only slightly.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: Your Imperial Majesty. I have served your father and your grandfather. I have watched this empire shrink year by year, and I have prayed every day that God would deliver us. But I would rather— I would rather die in a city that is still Constantinople than live in a city that has become a Latin colony with Greek decorations.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He sat. Silence. Kantakouzenos shifted in his seat. The old soldier's face was troubled—torn. He did not speak, but neither did he meet Juan's eyes. Father Gennadios stared at his hands. Whatever arguments he had prepared, they had withered. And the Emperor— The Emperor looked at Juan with the expression of a man watching a door close. Notaras had not said a word. He did not need to. He simply watched, that faint smile still playing at the corners of his mouth.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The position of the patriarch is made clear. He would rather die in the city as it falls to the muslims. Yesterday we made plans to fight. To fight and win. And I truly believe that we can win. We can do all the things we planned and hope for. I will always choose to fight, but not with someone who does not want my aid. I have offered everything and given everything that is reasonably in my power. And I would fight alongside you if you would have me. But I will not fight for a city that is already dead. Not fight if I am not wanted of course.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan looked around the room and made eye contact with everyone, one at a time.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Shall we not continue with the work of planning for a future? A future where Byzantium rises again? Or do we go on and wait until the Muslims eventually take the city? Shall we not at least make a plan? Not decide today, but plan for a future where the flame does not get snuffed out?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: John VIII opened his mouth as if to speak, then closed it. His eyes moved around the room, searching for guidance. No one offered it. The silence stretched. The coalition held by default because no one was willing to move first—in either direction.

encounters.recap: Juan appeals to the Byzantine council to continue planning for the future rather than waiting for the Ottoman conquest. Despite making eye contact with each member and reframing his proposals as mere planning rather than immediate decisions, the room remains paralyzed. Emperor John VIII nearly speaks but falls silent, searching for guidance that never comes. The patriarch's coalition holds through collective inaction rather than active agreement.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence stretched. Emperor John VIII stirred. His lips parted. The room seemed to hold its breath— And then nothing. His mouth closed. His eyes dropped to the table, then rose again, moving from face to face. The Patriarch. Notaras. Kantakouzenos. Gennadios. Juan. Searching. Waiting. No one spoke.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos sat rigid, his scarred hands flat on the table. A muscle worked in his jaw. He stared at a point somewhere beyond the wall, as if looking at something only he could see. Once, his eyes flicked to the Emperor—a question in them, or perhaps a plea—but the Emperor did not meet his gaze.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios had gone still as a man in prayer. His ink-stained fingers were laced together so tightly the knuckles had whitened. He studied the grain of the table with the intensity of a scholar examining sacred text. The guild representatives—the goldsmith, the cloth merchant Andreas, the shipwright—had pressed themselves back in their chairs. Men who had briefly imagined a future where their grandsons had work now looked like men who wished they had never entered this room.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch sat in perfect stillness. He had made his argument. He would not repeat it. His silence was its own statement: I have spoken truth. Now choose. And Notaras— Notaras watched. That faint smile had not left his face. He made no move to speak, no move to press the advantage. He simply waited, fingers steepled, eyes moving between Juan and the Emperor with the patience of a man who knows the river flows his way.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The silence grew heavier. Somewhere in the palace, a door closed. The sound echoed faintly through stone corridors. The Emperor's hands trembled slightly where they rested on the table. He drew a breath as if to speak again— And again, nothing.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos, you have not spoken yet. What do you think we should do. Would you continue with our planning like we did yesterday?

encounters.recap: The Byzantine council falls into paralyzed silence after Juan's proposal. Emperor John VIII cannot decide, searching faces for guidance that never comes. The coalition holds together only through inaction and fear of making the first move in either direction. Juan finally breaks the stalemate by directly addressing Kantakouzenos.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The council chamber doors had barely closed behind Juan when he turned to the nearest Castilian guard. "Find Captain Fernán. Don Juan de Sotomayor. Every senior officer we have. My chambers. Now." The guard saluted and ran.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Within the hour, the room was cramped with armored men. Captain Fernán stood nearest the door, his weathered face tight with concern. Don Juan de Sotomayor—who had held these walls for months with his three hundred knights—leaned against the wall, arms crossed, listening. Sergeant García waited by the window, eyes moving between the conversation and the courtyard below. Four other captains filled the remaining space, men who had sailed from Castile and survived the journey. Men Juan trusted.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Notaras moved sixty household guards into the eastern wing last night, Your Majesty. Well-armed. Professional—not street thugs. They control the corridor between the imperial apartments and the main gates. If they wanted to isolate us from our ships, that's the route they'd need to hold.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: My men have been in this city for eight months. I know the ground. The Blachernae palace has three main exits. East to the city proper—that's where Notaras's men are. North to the land walls—lightly guarded, Byzantine regulars, maybe twenty men. And west, a smaller gate leading to the harbor district. What do you need to know, Your Majesty?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Guards on your family—done. We'll rotate shifts, eight men at all times, our best. But Your Majesty should understand: sixty of Notaras's men in the palace, and only the routes I described. If this turns to open fighting inside these walls...

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome. Open ground. That's good—no ambush from corridors, no choke points. But it's also exposed. Multiple entrances. If someone wanted to cause trouble in a crowd...

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: We need to control who gets close to Your Majesty. A ring of our men around the speaking platform. Armed, visible. Not threatening—but present.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I can position my three hundred at the main entrances. They know the ground. The locals have seen them on the walls for months—some even respect them. But we cannot lock the Hippodrome down entirely. If we make it look like a Castilian military occupation, we lose before you speak a word.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The harbor gate is our escape route if things turn bad. I want twenty men there before dawn, holding it quietly. If we need to get Your Majesty to the ships in a hurry... What are your orders regarding Notaras's men? Do we watch them? Confront them? If they move to block our exits tonight...

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Understood. We hold our ground, we don't provoke, but we don't yield either. If they draw first, we'll be ready.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The construction crews—yes. Several hundred men, mostly local Greeks but paid from our treasury. They know where the coin comes from. We can have word spread tonight. Tools down at dawn, assemble at the Hippodrome. Some will come out of curiosity. Some out of loyalty to the pay. Some will stay home and see which way the wind blows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: The Hippodrome... I've walked it. The central spine is mostly intact—the old monuments, the obelisk, still standing. The racing ground itself... Weeds. Broken stones in places. Some debris where sections of seating have collapsed over the years. But the bones are there.

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: A few hundred men working through the night could clear the worst of it. Enough for horses to run without breaking legs, at least. Not a proper race—no maintained track, no starting gates. But a display? Knights on horseback, showing their skill?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: You want to give them a show. Remind them what Castilian cavalry looks like. Eight months I've been here, Your Majesty. These people have forgotten what strength looks like. They see tired soldiers on crumbling walls. They see merchants squabbling over scraps.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do it. And while we are acting like romans, why not go all the way? Can we buy a lot of bread for tomorrow? Bread and games...

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Bread and games. Your Majesty means to out-Roman the Romans.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: Eight months in this city. Eight months watching them cling to the memory of what they were. The titles. The ceremonies. The purple robes on an emperor who rules nothing. And you walk in and say—I will give you what Rome gave. What your emperors gave when Constantinople was the center of the world.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The bakeries in the harbor district—they supply the ships. Greek bakers, but they take Castilian coin readily enough. If we send men tonight with gold... For two thousand people, three thousand—we'd need... How much bread feeds a crowd?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: A loaf per family, distributed at the entrances. Three thousand loaves? Four? It's not about filling bellies—it's about the gesture. The memory of what emperors did.

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: The cost isn't the problem. We have treasury enough. The problem is time—can the bakeries produce that much overnight? And distribution. If we just pile bread at the gates, it becomes a mob. People trampled, fighting over loaves. We need organization. Lines. Our men handing out bread in orderly fashion.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Do it. See how much bread the bakers can bake for tomorrow. Our men will see for orderly distribution of the bread without anyone stealing. Anyone have anything we need to adress for now?

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: Queen Lucia and the Princess. Do they remain in the palace during the Hippodrome gathering, or do we move them to the ships? If things go badly—if Notaras decides to act while Your Majesty is in the arena—the palace is not secure. Sixty of his men between us and the harbor.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: There is also the question of what happens if the Emperor forbids the gathering. We have heard nothing from him since yesterday. He may wake tomorrow and send heralds commanding the Hippodrome closed. Do we obey? Defy him openly? We should know our answer before we are asked the question.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The emperor will not object. And if he is, then wake me or tell me immediately. He is invited after all to attend the council to discuss the future of the city after all. We just push on regardless, what can Notaras really do? Anyway, come to me if there is any trouble. Move the queen and Catalina to the ships tonight. Any more concerns?

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: The Patriarch. Your Majesty did not say what we do if he appears to denounce you before the crowd.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: And signals, Your Majesty. If trouble starts—if the crowd turns, if Notaras's men appear, if something happens we cannot foresee—how do we communicate? The Hippodrome is large. Noise will be great. Our men will be spread across multiple positions. Trumpets? Banners? We should have a sign that means 'withdraw to the harbor' that every man knows.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: We will use trumpets for signals. Communicate beforehand what each signal means. We should have a signal indeed to withdraw to a secure location. The most fortified location we control. A signal that calls for reinforcement. That's it I think.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Three signals then. One long blast—reinforcements needed, converge on the sound. Two short blasts—withdraw to secure position. The flagship and the harbor, Your Majesty? That would be our most defensible ground if the city turns against us.

exchanges.speaker: sergeant_garcia
exchanges.text: And a third signal. Three blasts. All clear, hold positions. So men do not mistake silence for disaster.

exchanges.speaker: juan_de_sotomayor
exchanges.text: I will send for the Queen and Princess within the hour. Quiet. Discreet. A small escort through the western gate—Notaras's men are watching the eastern wing, not the harbor side. By your leave, Your Majesty.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The captains stood straighter, the meeting concluding. Garcia and Fernán waited behind Sotomayor, ready to disperse into the fading afternoon—one to the bakeries with Castilian gold, one to secure the harbor gate, one to transform a ruined hippodrome into a stage for bread and games. The city beyond the window was beginning to glow amber in the lowering sun.

encounters.recap: Juan finalizes plans for a massive public demonstration at the Hippodrome, combining bread distribution with cavalry displays to win over Constantinople's population. His captains organize overnight preparations including clearing the racing ground, arranging thousands of loaves from Greek bakers, and establishing trumpet signals for crowd control. Queen Lucia and Princess Catalina are moved to the ships for safety while the city prepares for what could be Juan's boldest political gambit yet.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Night — Palace of Blachernae. Lucia did not argue when Juan explained. She simply nodded, gathered Catalina from her cradle, and began quietly directing the nursemaid to pack what was essential. "The ships," she said. Not a question. At the door, she paused. Catalina was asleep against her shoulder, tiny fingers curled into the fabric of her mother's dress. "Come back to us," Lucia said quietly. Then she was gone, surrounded by Sotomayor's men, disappearing into the darkness toward the western gate. Juan slept poorly. Dreams of crowds and fire and ancient stone.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Dawn — April 16, 1434. The morning came grey and cool, a thin mist rising from the Golden Horn. Juan dressed in his finest—not armor, but the rich cloth of a king. The crown of Castile. The chain bearing the cross of the crusade. Colors that would be visible across a stadium. Captain Fernán met him in the corridor.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: It's done, Your Majesty. The Hippodrome is cleared—enough for horses, at least. The bread... Four thousand loaves. The bakers worked through the night. Our men are already at the gates, distributing. Orderly. No fighting.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: And the crowd?

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: They're coming. But...

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Morning — The Hippodrome. The ancient stadium stretched before Juan in the pale morning light. His men had worked miracles overnight. The central racing ground had been cleared of the worst debris—weeds torn up, broken stones hauled aside, a rough but passable track visible in the packed earth. The great obelisk of Theodosius still stood at the center, its hieroglyphs watching over the proceedings as they had for a thousand years. At the gates, Castilian soldiers handed out bread in orderly lines. Juan could see the faces of those receiving—surprise, suspicion, gratitude, all mingled together. Some clutched their loaves and hurried inside. Others lingered, staring at the foreign soldiers who fed them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd that had gathered was substantial but not overwhelming. Perhaps two thousand souls scattered across the ancient seats. Juan's eye picked out the divisions immediately. Near the front, clustered together, the guildsmen. The shipwright was there, and the goldsmith, surrounded by men in work-stained clothes—craftsmen who had heard of ships to build and cannons to cast. They watched with guarded hope. Scattered among them, soldiers. Off-duty men from the walls, still wearing the marks of their service. Some had served alongside Sotomayor's knights for months. They stood straighter than the others, arms crossed, evaluating.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: But there were other faces too. Knots of black-robed priests positioned throughout the crowd, watching with hard eyes. They did not eat the bread. Near the eastern entrance, a cluster of better-dressed men—merchants, by their bearing, their fine clothes slightly threadbare. Notaras's people, almost certainly. They spoke quietly among themselves, gesturing toward the Castilian knights. And everywhere, the uncertain—common folk who had heard rumors and come to see for themselves. They held their bread and waited, neither hostile nor friendly. Simply... waiting.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Near the ancient imperial box, the familiar figures. Kantakouzenos in military dress, face unreadable, standing apart from the crowd. Father Gennadios beside him, dark eyes moving across the scene. The shipwright and goldsmith had positioned themselves nearby, as if seeking protection in proximity to power. No Emperor. No Patriarch. No Notaras—at least not visible. One hundred Castilian knights sat mounted at the far end of the racing ground, horses stamping, armor gleaming. A display of power that needed no translation. The crowd's murmur fell to silence as Juan walked to the center of the Hippodrome. They were waiting.

roll.outcome: Bread Wins Bellies. The four thousand loaves do their work. People who came suspicious leave with full hands. The crowd grows modestly—perhaps three thousand now—and the mood shifts from wary to curious. Not converted, but willing to listen. The priests who refuse to eat look increasingly isolated.

encounters.recap: Juan prepares for a critical public gathering at the Hippodrome, distributing bread and clearing the ancient stadium for horse races. The crowd of two thousand grows to three thousand as the free bread wins over the skeptical populace, though divisions remain visible between supporters, opponents, and the uncertain masses who simply wait to see what the Castilian king will do.

A display of power that needed no translation. The crowd's murmur fell to silence as Juan walked to the center of the Hippodrome. They were waiting.

encounters.recap: Juan's bread distribution and horse races in the Hippodrome have a modest positive impact on the crowd. The free bread draws people who came suspicious, growing attendance to three thousand and shifting the mood from wary to curious, though the crowd remains unconverted.

roll.outcome: Watching and Waiting. A calculated decision: let Juan have his spectacle, then use it against him. Agents take careful note of who attends, who accepts bread, who cheers. Priests observe but do not interfere. They are building a case, not fighting a battle. The reckoning comes later.

encounters.recap: While Juan distributes bread and prepares his Hippodrome spectacle, Notaras and the Patriarch choose a strategic response of observation rather than direct confrontation. Their agents and priests watch carefully, documenting attendance and reactions, building evidence for future use rather than risking immediate opposition that might backfire.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The crowd of nearly three thousand waited, bread in hand, curious and cautious. Priests stood among them, silent observers. The hundred mounted knights held formation at the far end, horses stamping. Kantakouzenos caught Juan's eye and gave a single, curt nod.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Citizens of Constantinople! I have come before you and your city to present you with a choice. I assume many of you already know this, but let me just repeat regardless. Your emperor has asked me for help in these times and I foresee three futures for the city. The first choice is to relocate the city. I offer refuge for those willing to come and will fully respect both your culture and religion. The city will fall to the turks, but at least you are safe in a place where you can keep your religion alive. The second choice is to let me lead the fight against the Ottomans. I will bring the sword of christianity down on the turks and will drive them from the continent. I can only do this if you as well commit to this fight. If we fight then we fight with everything we have and with everyone. I will implement the ancient noble obligations again and we turn our full attention to not only survive but to restore the city to it's glory. Latins will be allowed to own property, giving the city some much needed work and population. We need to grow is we need to win. I will bring thousands of christian soldiers to this fight. If we win, latin christians and orthodox christians will live side by side as brothers under the rule of an orthodox king. I fully realize that I ask you to place your trust in me and that latin kings have betrayed you before. Therefore, I ask you not to choose today, but to rather think about it and make the choice later, after a few years when you have had time to think about it. The third choice is what happens when the city rejects the other choices. I will have repaired your walls and I will leave back to Iberia. I will not help those who do not want help. The past few days, I have spent speaking with those who will make this choice. And it only seemed proper to inform the citizens as well. And to enjoy this old location again. It is overdue some good use. We will have some races later. But first, let's discuss what the city should do.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The final words of Juan's speech hung in the morning air. For a moment—silence. The guildsmen near the front shifted, hands half-raised to applaud. The shipwright's weathered face held something like hope. Then, from the eastern section of the crowd—where the well-dressed men had clustered—a voice rang out. It was not a shout. It was a question, pitched to carry. The voice of a man accustomed to speaking in markets and councils. Heads turned. The speaker stood among the merchant crowd—fine clothes, trimmed beard, the bearing of money. One of Notaras's people, almost certainly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The guildsmen near the front tried to respond—shouts of 'Let him speak!' and 'He offers help!'—but the hostile voices were positioned throughout the crowd, and they knew how to project. The chant was spreading. 'Byzantine Constantinople! Byzantine Constantinople!' The hundred mounted knights at the far end of the Hippodrome stirred, horses sensing the change in atmosphere. Captain Fernán, positioned near the speaking platform, caught Juan's eye—a question in his gaze. The crowd had not turned violent. Not yet. But the moment was slipping away, the careful stage-setting dissolving into chaos of competing voices.

roll.outcome: The Empty Box. Someone points at the imperial viewing platform. 'The Emperor is not here! Even our own ruler does not endorse this!' The observation spreads like fire. Whatever Juan said is now overshadowed by what John VIII's absence says. The crowd grows restless, confused. Why should they listen to a foreign king their own emperor will not stand beside?

encounters.recap: Juan delivers a carefully crafted speech to three thousand citizens in the Hippodrome, offering three choices for Constantinople's future. Despite the thoughtful content, the crowd's reaction turns hostile when planted voices question the Emperor's absence, leading to chants of 'Byzantine Constantinople!' and threatening to derail the entire gathering.

encounters.recap: Juan's three-choice speech to the Constantinople crowd was met with organized opposition. Hostile voices, likely coordinated by Notaras's agents, challenged the Emperor's absence and Juan's authority to speak for the city. The moment deteriorated into competing chants of 'Byzantine Constantinople!' despite some support from guildsmen and workers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The final words of Juan's speech hung in the morning air. For a moment—silence. The guildsmen near the front shifted, hands half-raised to applaud. The shipwright's weathered face held something like hope. Then, from the eastern section of the crowd—where the well-dressed men had clustered—a voice rang out.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The speaker stood among the merchant crowd—fine clothes, trimmed beard, the bearing of money. One of Notaras's people, almost certainly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "Where is our Emperor?" It was not a shout. It was a question, pitched to carry. The voice of a man accustomed to speaking in markets and councils. Heads turned.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "Why does a Latin speak for Constantinople?" Another voice now, from a different part of the crowd. Coordinated. Prepared. "Does the Emperor endorse this?" A third voice. "Where is John Palaiologos?"

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The guildsmen near the front tried to respond—shouts of "Let him speak!" and "He offers help!"—but the hostile voices were positioned throughout the crowd, and they knew how to project. "Byzantine Constantinople!" someone began to chant, and others took it up. Not the whole crowd—not even most of it—but enough. Enough to shatter the moment, to turn attention from Juan's words to the contest of voices.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The priests watched in silence. They did not chant. They did not need to. Kantakouzenos had uncrossed his arms, his hand moving instinctively toward where a sword would hang. Father Gennadios's face had gone tight with concern. The shipwright looked around wildly, uncertain what to do.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The emperor has been attending these discussions and will arrive shortly, along with the patriarch. I expect them any minute, but they know about everything I have indicated. Maybe we should have some races while we wait for them.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan's voice cut through the chanting, pitched to carry across the ancient stadium. The hostile voices faltered—Loss of momentum. The man who had asked the question first looked uncertain. He had expected no answer, or a weak one. Not a confident assertion that the Emperor was expected.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan's signal reached the mounted knights. A trumpet sounded—clear and sharp—and the hundred Castilian riders began to move into formation at the starting line. The crowd's attention shifted. Horses. Armor gleaming in the morning light. The thunder of hooves on packed earth as the knights guided their mounts into position.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "Races!" A child's voice, somewhere in the crowd. "Mama, horses!" The chant of "Byzantine Constantinople" died away, replaced by the murmur of anticipation. Whatever their politics, these were people who had grown up on stories of the Hippodrome's glory. Chariot races. Imperial spectacles. The roar of a hundred thousand voices.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Send some men to the palace and get the emperor here to attend these races now! The patriarch can come on his own, but I need the emperor here now.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: Sergeant García! The palace. Now. The King's compliments to His Imperial Majesty, and his presence is requested at the games being held in his honor.

exchanges.speaker: garcia
exchanges.text: And if he refuses, Captain?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The question hung in the air. The Emperor had not attended. Had not endorsed. Had spent the night being turned by Notaras and the Patriarch. Sixty of Notaras's guards stood between the eastern wing and the main gates. Sending men to request the Emperor was one thing. Sending men to fetch him was another.

encounters.recap: Hostile voices from Notaras's supporters challenge Juan's authority and demand the Emperor's presence. Juan deflects by promising the Emperor's imminent arrival and ordering horse races to distract the crowd. He then commands his men to fetch the Emperor from the palace, creating a critical moment where refusal could expose his claims as false.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: If you go yourself, King of Castile, you force the Emperor's hand. He cannot refuse you to your face without declaring open opposition. But you also leave three thousand people here, wondering where the Latin king went. And Notaras's agents will have half an hour to work on them without you present. Send men, and risk refusal from a distance. Go yourself, and risk losing what you have built here. A soldier's choice. Bad options and worse options.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I must face the emperor now. Kantakouzenos, try and keep the crowds entertained as best you can. I will be back soon. I leave immediately to the palace and take a large guard with me.

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: I am no master of ceremonies, King of Castile. But I can keep soldiers entertained.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: I will help. The people know my face, if not my endorsement. Go quickly. And... be careful.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Fifty knights formed up around Juan within moments—half of Fernán's reserve force, armed and mounted. The crowd barely noticed their departure; the first race had begun, hooves thundering on packed earth, and all eyes were on the riders. Through the streets of Constantinople. The city looked different at speed. Crumbling facades blurred past. Empty lots where great buildings once stood. Faces turning to watch the column of Castilian cavalry—surprise, fear, curiosity. The Blachernae rose before them—not a single building but a complex of structures, walls within walls, the accumulated architecture of centuries. The main gate stood open, Byzantine regulars in their positions. They did not move to stop Juan's column. But their eyes followed every rider. Inside the first courtyard, movement. Men in different livery—Notaras's household guards. Perhaps twenty of them, positioned near the passage to the imperial apartments.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: One of them—an officer, by his bearing—stepped forward. His Greek was formal, his face carefully blank.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: King of Castile. The palace is not expecting visitors this morning.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I thank you and Notaras, but I have an important meeting with the emperor now. He knows this. Follow me and dont stop. We keep walking.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The officer raised a hand. Your Majesty, I must send word ahead. Protocol requires— But Juan was already moving. His knights followed, horses walking forward with the steady inevitability of a tide. The officer's face flickered—loss of control, calculation, decision. He stepped back. His men shifted, parting reluctantly, falling back step by step as the column of Castilian knights pressed through the passage. Runner! the officer barked in Greek. A younger guard broke away, sprinting down a side corridor toward the imperial apartments. Through a courtyard. Past a fountain, dry and cracked. Under an archway carved with Byzantine eagles. The imperial wing rose ahead—older architecture, grander in its decay. More guards here. Byzantine regulars this time, not Notaras's men. They watched the approaching column with confusion, looking to each other for guidance. The runner had reached them. He was speaking rapidly to an officer in imperial livery, gesturing back toward Juan's column. The imperial officer stepped forward, positioning himself at the entrance to the wing. Behind him, a heavy wooden door—closed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: King of Castile. The Emperor has not summoned you. I cannot admit— He stopped. From somewhere beyond the door, raised voices. Greek, too muffled to make out. An argument. Then silence. The imperial officer looked back at the door, then at Juan, visibly unsure of what to do.

roll.outcome: Delayed but Not Stopped. The officer attempts to stall but Juan's men keep walking, forcing the guards to yield step by step. A runner warns someone ahead. Juan will reach the Emperor, but not unannounced.

encounters.recap: Juan leaves the Hippodrome with fifty knights to confront the Emperor directly at the Palace of Blachernae. Despite attempts by Notaras's guards to delay him and protocol objections from imperial guards, Juan's column forces its way through the palace courtyards, reaching the entrance to the Emperor's wing where muffled arguments can be heard beyond a closed door.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: "King of Castile." His Greek was formal, his face carefully blank. "The palace is not expecting visitors this morning."

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Follow me and dont stop. We keep walking.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I thank you and Notaras, but I have an important meeting with the emperor now. He knows this.

roll.outcome: Delayed but Not Stopped. The officer attempts to stall. "I must send word ahead, Your Majesty. Protocol requires—" But Juan's men keep walking, and the guards must choose: fight or yield. They yield, falling back step by step, buying time for a runner to warn someone ahead. Juan will reach the Emperor, but not unannounced.

encounters.recap: Juan confronts Notaras's guards blocking his path to the Emperor at the Palace of Blachernae. Despite the officer's attempts to stall with protocol requirements, Juan's determination and fifty armed knights force the guards to fall back step by step, though they send a runner ahead to warn of his approach.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Juan reached the door and pushed it open. The cabinet chamber was filled with morning light through tall windows. The same table where they had argued about crowns and choices. Emperor John VIII stood at the window, his back to the room, his shoulders rigid. Patriarch Joseph II sat in a high-backed chair, ancient hands gripping the armrests. His sharp eyes fixed on Juan the moment the door opened. A third man—a court functionary in Byzantine robes—stood between them, mouth still open mid-sentence.

exchanges.speaker: patriarch_joseph_ii
exchanges.text: You dare.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am here to invite the Emperor if he wants to attend the important talks about the future of his empire. Like we discussed yesterday, we would continue our talks at the Hippodrome. Right now, the people of the city are enjoying the races, but I would rather continue with the emperor present. I was a bit surprised you have not been attending.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Emperor turned from the window. His face was not the hollow, exhausted mask Juan had seen these past days. Something had hardened there. Wounded pride, crystallized into cold fury.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: You force your way into my home. You stage games for my people. In my Hippodrome. Without my permission. You distribute bread as if you were already their emperor. You tell crowds I am expected—as if I were your servant to summon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch had gone still, watching with sharp, satisfied eyes.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: I have ruled this empire for nine years. Nine years of holding together what remains. Of paying tribute to survive. Of swallowing pride so that my people might live another day. And you—you arrive with your knights and your gold and your choices—and within three days you treat me as an obstacle to be pushed aside.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He stopped perhaps five feet from Juan.

exchanges.speaker: john_viii_palaiologos
exchanges.text: No. I will not come. I will not be paraded before my own people as proof of your authority. I will not dance to your tune, King of Castile. Return to your Hippodrome. Enjoy your races. Distribute your bread. Play at being emperor for a morning. But do not summon me again. I am not yours to command.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Patriarch's ancient face held something that might have been triumph. The functionary stood frozen, barely breathing. Fifty Castilian knights waited in the corridor beyond.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: The world exists of choices my emperor. You are making one right now and I will respect it, as I will respect the will and choice of the people of what is left of the empire. I wish you well.

roll.outcome: Bitter Refusal. The Emperor turns at last. His face is hard with wounded pride. He refuses to attend, declaring he will not be summoned like a servant or dance to Juan's tune.

encounters.recap: Juan enters the palace cabinet chamber to invite Emperor John VIII to continue their talks at the Hippodrome, but finds the Emperor with the Patriarch. The Emperor, his pride wounded by Juan's actions over recent days, delivers a bitter refusal, accusing Juan of treating him like a servant and declaring he will not be paraded before his own people. Juan respectfully accepts the Emperor's choice and departs.

roll.outcome: Bitter Refusal. The Emperor turns at last. His face is hard with wounded pride. "You force your way into my home. You stage games for my people without my permission. You tell crowds I am expected, as if I were your servant to summon." His voice shakes. "No. I will not come. I will not dance to your tune. Return to your Hippodrome, King of Castile. Enjoy your races. I have nothing more to say to you."

encounters.recap: Juan arrived at the palace to invite the Emperor to continue their discussions at the Hippodrome during the races. Caught between the intimidating Patriarch and Juan's implied pressure, the Emperor's wounded pride finally asserted itself in bitter refusal, rejecting the invitation and dismissing Juan entirely.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The races were still running. Kantakouzenos stood near the imperial box, arms crossed, watching the track with the critical eye of a military man evaluating cavalry. Father Gennadios was moving through the crowd near the front, speaking with guildsmen, his black cassock visible among the work-stained clothes. The crowd had not grown. Had not shrunk. Perhaps three thousand souls, still divided—hopeful faces near the front, suspicious clusters further back, priests watching from the edges. But something had shifted. Eyes turned toward Juan as he rode in. The murmurs began immediately. He went to the palace. He came back alone. Where is the Emperor? Kantakouzenos saw him. The old soldier's face was grim. He walked toward Juan's position, his pace deliberate.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Citizens of Constantinople, I have just visited the emperor and he has decided not to come to the races and to discuss the future of the empire. This makes it difficult for me to come to your aid. You know what the choices are. I am available for anyone who wants to discuss the future of Constantinople that keeps it christian. Those who do not, they are in my prayers and I wish them well. Let us enjoy another race for now, then let us speak of the future.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words echoed across the ancient stones. The Emperor has decided not to come. The crowd stirred. Murmurs rippled outward like waves from a dropped stone. People looked at each other—neighbors, strangers, seeking guidance in other faces. Finding only the same uncertainty reflected back. The races continued at the far end of the track, but fewer eyes watched them now. A long pause. The kind of silence that has weight. Then—movement. A single man stepped forward from the crowd. Middle-aged, rough clothes, dust on his hands and in his hair. One of the wall workers. He walked toward the Castilian line with the deliberate pace of a man who has decided something and fears he will lose his nerve if he slows down. The knights let him approach. Searched him. He had no weapons. They directed him to wait. Another man followed. Then a woman—older, a merchant's wife by her dress, clutching a half-eaten loaf of Castilian bread. Then two more workers together, glancing at each other for courage. Perhaps ten people in total. Maybe twelve. They clustered near the speaking platform, watched by three thousand others who did not move. The guildsmen near the front shifted, some half-stepping forward, then stopping. The shipwright's face was twisted with indecision. The goldsmith stared at the ground. Notaras's agents watched from the edges, marking faces. The priests observed in silence. Kantakouzenos stood apart, arms crossed, his scarred face revealing nothing. Father Gennadios had paused his movements through the crowd, watching Juan. Twelve people. Brave or desperate or both. The rest of Constantinople waited to see what would happen to those who stepped forward first.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: What is it you want to tell me? You have my ear.

roll.outcome: Hesitation. The announcement lands heavily. People look at each other. No one wants to move first. Then one man—a worker from the wall crews—steps forward alone. Then another. Perhaps eight, ten people total. Enough to have a conversation. Not enough to call a movement.

encounters.recap: After announcing the Emperor's refusal to meet, Juan addresses the crowd again, offering to speak with anyone interested in keeping Constantinople Christian. The crowd reacts with hesitation—only about twelve brave souls step forward while three thousand others watch and wait, creating a tense moment of division in the city.

roll.outcome: Hesitation. The announcement lands heavily. People look at each other. No one wants to move first. A long, uncomfortable pause. Then one man—a worker from the wall crews—steps forward alone. Then another. Perhaps eight, ten people total. Enough to have a conversation. Not enough to call a movement.

encounters.recap: After Juan's second speech to the crowd about the Emperor's rejection and his continued availability to help, a roll determined the crowd's response. The result showed hesitation and fear, with only eight to ten brave souls stepping forward to speak with the king, while most of the crowd remained uncertain and fearful of taking sides.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The words echoed across the ancient stones. The Emperor has decided not to come. The crowd stirred. Murmurs rippled outward like waves from a dropped stone. People looked at each other—neighbors, strangers, seeking guidance in other faces. Finding only the same uncertainty reflected back. The races continued at the far end of the track, but fewer eyes watched them now. A long pause. The kind of silence that has weight. Then—movement. A single man stepped forward from the crowd. Middle-aged, rough clothes, dust on his hands and in his hair. One of the wall workers. He walked toward the Castilian line with the deliberate pace of a man who has decided something and fears he will lose his nerve if he slows down. The knights let him approach. Searched him. He had no weapons. They directed him to wait. Another man followed. Then a woman—older, a merchant's wife by her dress, clutching a half-eaten loaf of Castilian bread. Then two more workers together, glancing at each other for courage. Perhaps ten people in total. Maybe twelve. They clustered near the speaking platform, watched by three thousand others who did not move. The guildsmen near the front shifted, some half-stepping forward, then stopping. The shipwright's face was twisted with indecision. The goldsmith stared at the ground. Notaras's agents watched from the edges, marking faces. The priests observed in silence. Kantakouzenos stood apart, arms crossed, his scarred face revealing nothing. Father Gennadios had paused his movements through the crowd, watching Juan. Twelve people. Brave or desperate or both. The rest of Constantinople waited to see what would happen to those who stepped forward first.

He moves among them, shaking hands and speaking as equals. A roll determines their response: while they accept the mission, the cost becomes real as they realize the danger, with visible fear about potential consequences from Notaras's men.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Venetian quarter hugged the Golden Horn, a city within a city. Walls within walls. The gates were manned by Venetian guards in the livery of the Republic—not Byzantine soldiers. They watched Juan's approaching column with sharp, calculating eyes. The quarter had been barricaded since the fighting three days past. A murdered Genoese merchant. Four dead. The fifteen-year-old Greek baker's apprentice caught between. The scars were still visible—a burned awning here, a boarded window there.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Inside, the quarter felt more like Venice than Constantinople. Narrow streets. Brick and stone in the Italian style. The sound of Italian dialects, the smell of commerce. Warehouses lined the waterfront. Ships rode at anchor, the winged lion of St. Mark flying from their masts. By the time Juan reached the central square, a reception had assembled. Not hostile—but not warm. Merchants in fine cloth. Warehouse factors with ink-stained fingers. Guards positioned at every corner, hands near weapons.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: And in the center, waiting: a man of perhaps fifty, silver-haired, dressed in the black robes of a Venetian patrician. His face was a mask of careful courtesy.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Your Majesty of Castile. I am Marco Contarini, bailo of the Venetian community in Constantinople. We are... honored by your visit.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Thank you. I have arrived a few days ago in the city and I would be remisce if I did not visit you. I am also drafting a document stating what choices are ahead for the people of the city and would like to have your thoughts on it as well. I came to learn.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini's mask of courtesy did not slip, but something sharpened behind his eyes. He gestured toward a building facing the square—stone facade, iron-bound doors, the winged lion carved above the lintel. Inside, the building was cooler, darker. A receiving room with maps on the walls—the Mediterranean, the Black Sea, trade routes marked in faded ink. Chairs arranged around a table. Wine already poured, as if Juan's visit had been anticipated.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: You speak of choices for the people of the city. We have heard... rumors. From the Hippodrome. From the palace. They say you propose to let Latin Christians own property throughout Constantinople. Not just in the quarters. This is... significant, Your Majesty. The quarters exist for reasons. Reasons of history. Reasons of law. Reasons of—safety. What precisely are you proposing? And what would it mean for Venice?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Well, that is exactly what I am here to discuss. I was thinking about not dissolving the quarters. Unfortunately, the tension built up over centuries does not go away. But I could let latin christians own and operate property in the city. Venetians inside and outside of the quarters. Would this align with Venetian interests?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini's fingers traced the rim of his wine cup. The gesture of a man buying time to think. He rose and moved to one of the maps on the wall—the Mediterranean, trade routes inked in red and blue.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Venice has held privileges in Constantinople for three hundred years. Since the time of the Comneni emperors. We have bled for this city. Paid for it. Our gold rebuilt walls. Our ships defended harbors. The quarter is not merely where we live. It is where we are safe. Where Venetian law protects Venetian merchants. Where the events of 1182 cannot repeat. If Venetians can own property throughout the city... yes, there are opportunities. Warehouses closer to certain markets. Workshops beyond the quarter walls. Room to expand. But also risks. A Venetian alone in a Greek neighborhood, when tensions rise? A Venetian subject to Byzantine courts instead of Venetian justice?

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: And there is another question, Your Majesty. You say Latin Christians. Not Venetians. The Genoese. They would have the same rights? Own property beside us, compete with us, in the same streets? Venice and Genoa have been at war more often than at peace. Three days ago, blood was spilled between our quarters over a murdered merchant. If your proposal means Venetians and Genoese expanding into the same districts, building warehouses side by side... I must be honest, Your Majesty. That is not a recipe for peace. That is a recipe for the violence of our quarters spreading throughout the entire city.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Genoese, Aragonese, Florentine, yes every christian can live and own property in the city. Surely fellow christians can keep the peace among one another? The quarters remain and everyone outside of it obeys the kings justice and peace.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Surely fellow Christians can keep the peace. Your Majesty, I mean no disrespect, but... have you met Genoese? Venice and Genoa have fought four wars in the last century. Wars, Your Majesty. Fleets burning. Thousands dead. We have sacked each other's colonies, blockaded each other's ports, slaughtered each other's merchants from the Black Sea to the Atlantic. Three days ago, four men died over a single murdered merchant. Not a war—a rumor of insult. You speak of the king's justice. But which king? The Emperor who hides in his palace and cannot control his own nobles? Or do you mean your justice, Your Majesty? Castilian law over Venetian citizens?

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Venice has treaties. Ancient treaties. Our merchants answer to Venetian courts, Venetian law, the Bailo's justice—my justice. This is not pride. This is survival. It is what allows a Venetian to trade here without fear that a Byzantine judge, paid by a Greek competitor, will rule against him. If you propose that Venetians outside the quarter fall under Byzantine law—or Castilian law—you ask us to surrender protections our ancestors died for. What does Venice gain that is worth such a price?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Can the Venetians not maintain their own laws in the quarters and obey Byzantine laws outside it? Would this not grant you the opportunity you seek to expand and gain better warehouse access? Nothing would be taken away, only opportunity gained.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini paused. For the first time, something shifted in his expression. The mask of diplomatic caution cracked slightly, revealing genuine calculation beneath.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Nothing taken away. Only opportunity gained. That is... not an unreasonable framework, Your Majesty. A Venetian who wishes to remain under Venetian law stays in the quarter. A Venetian who sees opportunity beyond the walls accepts Byzantine jurisdiction for his ventures there. Choice, not compulsion. But I must ask the practical questions. The questions my merchants will ask me. First: Byzantine law as enforced by whom? The Emperor cannot control Notaras. Notaras controls half the judges in this city through debt and favor. If a Venetian outside the quarter finds himself before a Byzantine court, and his Greek competitor has paid the judge...

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: Second: you speak of the king's peace. But you are not king here, Your Majesty. Not yet. Perhaps not ever, if the Emperor continues to refuse you. If I counsel my merchants to expand beyond the quarter, and then you sail away, what protects them? Third: the Genoese. If we expand, they expand. Every opportunity for Venice is an opportunity for Genoa. Every warehouse we build, they build one beside it. This is not abstract rivalry. This is life and death. Our merchants hate each other, Your Majesty. Generations of hate. You cannot decree that away.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: I am not refusing. I am... considering. But Venice does not make decisions quickly. We deliberate. We consult. What you propose could benefit us greatly—or destroy us entirely. The difference lies in details you have not yet provided.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me tell you what will happen. I am putting the choice for the survival of the city on paper today. I cannot grant the latin christians these rights, but I will make it conditional if the Byzantines call upon me to save the city from the turks. The framing will be: 'If the Byzantines ask me to defend the city, I accept and that also will mean that latins will be able to own property, own lands, basically have the same rights as Byzantines have. I will conduct a thorough review of the legal system and it's judges and adopt laws that improve commerce and fair adjudication of this law. No more bribed judges by Notaras.' That will be the framing. This is what it will cost the Byzantines if they ask the latins to fight for their city. Are there other things you think I should include?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini's eyebrows rose slightly. He leaned back in his chair.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: You are asking Venice for counsel on how to reshape Constantinople. That is... unexpected. And not unwelcome. If you wish to attract Latin merchants—not just tolerate them, but attract them—there are things that matter. First: contracts. Byzantine law is... ancient. Cumbersome. A dispute over a cargo can take months in their courts. Venice has commercial courts that resolve such matters in days. If you want Venetian—and yes, Genoese, Florentine, Catalan—merchants to invest beyond the quarters, you need courts that move quickly and rule fairly.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini's expression shifted—something relaxing in the set of his shoulders.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: You have thought about this more carefully than I expected, Your Majesty. This is not the bluster of a crusader. This is the mind of a king who understands trade. What else is in this document of yours?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will replace the old system of taxation with crown appointed tax assessors. Reduce corruption. Predictable rates. exchanges.speaker: narrator

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: A few years. If the Byzantines accept. If you enact these reforms. If... Let us suppose it happens.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He turned to face Juan.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: But there are dangers, Your Majesty. Venice and Genoa, competing in the same streets—I have spoken of this. exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I will see it through, dont worry. But, now lets see what happens if the shoe is on the other foot. If the Turks take the city, what then happens to christian trade? What happens to Venice here?

exchanges.speaker: narrator

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: If the Turks take the city. Venice is... pragmatic, Your Majesty. We have traded with Muslims before. Egypt. The Mamluks. We trade with the Ottomans even now—through intermediaries, through neutral ports. Commerce does not require friendship. Only stability.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: If Constantinople falls, the Ottomans control the straits. Every ship passing to the Black Sea pays tribute to the Sultan. Every cargo of grain, every bale of furs, every slave—taxed by Ottoman customs. Venice would negotiate. We always negotiate. Perhaps we keep some privileges. Perhaps we pay higher duties. Perhaps... He has his own merchants, his own ships, his own routes.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: And there is the other matter. The one we do not speak of in polite company. The Ottomans are not... gentle conquerors. When they take a city by force, there is sack. Plunder. exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: We tell ourselves we can negotiate. Adapt. Survive. Perhaps we can. Perhaps Venice endures as a trading partner of the Ottoman Empire. But Constantinople—this quarter—these people? That is the truth, Your Majesty. The truth we do not like to say aloud.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: So you would be prepared to prevent this future then? Can I count on your support to prevent this from happening? I am a devout christian king and I have different motives from yours. But I think our interests align strongly in this. Shall we make Constantinople a powerfull christian trading city?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Contarini's fingers drummed once on the table. Twice. The silence stretched.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: You ask if you can count on my support. I am the bailo. I speak for Venice in Constantinople—but I do not speak for Venice. I cannot commit the Republic to war. I cannot promise ships, gold, soldiers. That requires the Doge. The Senate. Deliberation. But.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: I can tell you what I can do. I can write to Venice tonight. A full account of what you have proposed. The commercial courts. The property rights. The tax reforms. The choice you are putting before the Byzantines. I can write it favorably, Your Majesty. I can frame it as opportunity rather than risk. I can recommend that the Senate send an envoy to speak with you directly.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: And here, in this city, I can keep the peace in this quarter. I can tell my merchants to wait. To watch. To not flee at the first rumor of Ottoman sails. I can tell them that there is a Latin king who speaks of something new. Something worth considering.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: He extended his hand.

exchanges.speaker: marco_contarini
exchanges.text: I cannot promise Venice, Your Majesty. But I can promise Marco Contarini. I will not work against you. I will counsel patience to my people. And I will write to the Doge tonight. Is that enough? For now?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I would not yet write to Venice just yet. I am still drafting the document that contains the choice. What it will definitively contain and how it is recieved by the city will matter. Let us now speak of the current conflict with Genoa. What can be done to bury the hatchet? If we want this city of commerce to be believable, a good way to demonstrate this is if this conflict can be resolved soon. What is the situation?

encounters.recap: Juan presents his conditional reform proposal to Contarini: if Byzantines request Latin aid, comprehensive economic and legal reforms would transform Constantinople into a thriving Christian commercial center. Contarini analyzes both the transformative potential and catastrophic consequences of Ottoman conquest, offering personal support while acknowledging Venice's need for formal deliberation.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The Genoese quarter lay further along the Golden Horn, separated from the Venetian quarter by a stretch of Byzantine streets that now served as a no-man's-land. Juan's column passed shuttered shops, empty market stalls, nervous faces peering from windows. The violence had spread fear beyond the Latin quarters themselves. The Genoese walls were higher than the Venetians'. Older. The red cross of St. George flew from towers that looked more like fortifications than commercial buildings. Guards lined the battlements—more than seemed necessary for a trading post. The gates were closed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A Genoese officer appeared above the gatehouse, looking down at Juan's column with undisguised suspicion. Behind Juan, his knights shifted. Fifty armed men, waiting in the street, being refused entry by a trading company's guards. The insult was not subtle. From somewhere beyond the walls, shouted orders in Genoese dialect. The sound of men moving into position. The officer waited, arms crossed, for Juan's response.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am Juan of Castille. I humbly request an audience with the podesta if he will have me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The officer did not move. Did not open the gates. Did not refuse outright. Instead, he disappeared from the battlements. Minutes passed. Juan's knights waited in the street, hands near weapons, eyes on the crossbowmen visible along the walls. The afternoon sun beat down. Somewhere in the quarter, voices argued in rapid Genoese—too distant to make out words, but the tone was clear. Disagreement. Debate.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: A different face appeared above the gate. Older. A clerk, by his dress, ink stains on his fingers. Before Juan could answer, another question. The clerk's face was carefully neutral, but the question was not. A third voice from somewhere behind the walls—shouted in Genoese, translated by the clerk a moment later. The gates remained closed. More voices behind the walls. The argument continuing. The clerk waited, stylus poised as if to record Juan's answers.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His Majesty of Castile, the podestà would know the purpose of your visit. Did His Majesty visit the Venetian quarter before coming here? What was discussed with the Venetians? Does the King of Castile come as Venice's ambassador, or his own man?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I did just visited the Venetian quarter. I am visiting this city in response to a desperate plea from it's emperor for aid. I am currently learning how I can best aid the city and that includes the quarters of the venetians and the genoese. I visited the Venetians first at random. There was no ulterior motive behind visiting them first and do not mean to favor them above Genoa. I am neutral in the conflict. I meant no disrespect and I apologize if Genoa has taken offence. I would like to discuss matters of trade and common christian interests while I am in the city if the podesta would be gracious to receive me.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The clerk's stylus scratched. He disappeared from view. More waiting. More muffled argument behind the walls. The sun had moved noticeably by the time the clerk returned. A pause. Another voice from behind—older, rougher, speaking Genoese. The clerk listened, then translated. The gates remained closed. But something had shifted. A smaller door—set into the main gate—creaked open slightly. Not an invitation. A possibility. The clerk's face appeared in the gap.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: His Majesty's words have been conveyed to the podestà. The podestà observes that the King of Castile speaks of neutrality. Genoa would test this neutrality. A Genoese merchant lies dead. Murdered. His name was Domenico Fieschi—a name of some importance in Genoa. The Venetians shelter his killer. If His Majesty is truly neutral, the podestà would hear His Majesty say so regarding this matter. Not regarding trade. Not regarding common interests. Regarding blood. The podestà asks directly: Does the King of Castile believe Genoa is owed justice for the murder of Domenico Fieschi? Or does he come to tell us, as the Byzantines do, to swallow our grief for the sake of peace? Answer this, Your Majesty, and the podestà will receive you. Genoa does not ask you to take sides. Only to acknowledge that a wrong was done.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I am a christian and believe in the principles of justice and of due court. A man has been killed and the matter is unresolved. I believe in justice in this and other matters. I believe that this matter has become more than just one man being killed, it has become a fight between the Venetian and the Genoese quarters. I do not take sides in a fight between cities for I am indeed neutral. I do pledge myself in the service of justice for the fate of this man. In the fight between the Italian cities, I take no side. A wrong was done and I will do whatever is in my power to right it, I do so acknowledge.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The clerk studied Juan's face for a long moment. Then he withdrew. The small door creaked wider. Not the main gates—Genoa would not grant that dignity—but passage nonetheless. Beyond the door, a narrow street lined with armed Genoese. Not an honor guard—a gauntlet. Hard faces, hands on weapons, eyes following Juan's every movement. The message was clear: You are tolerated, not welcomed.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The building was fortress as much as residence. Thick walls. Iron-barred windows. The red cross of St. George everywhere—carved in stone, painted on wood, stitched into banners. Raffaele Lomellini waited in a receiving room that felt more like a war council chamber. Maps on the walls. Ledgers stacked on tables. A half-eaten meal pushed aside, as if interrupted by news of Juan's arrival. The podestà was perhaps forty-five, broad-shouldered, with a scarred jaw and eyes that held no warmth. He did not rise when Juan entered. Did not bow.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: King of Castile. You acknowledge a wrong was done. Good. This is more than the Venetians have offered.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lomellini was silent. His scarred face worked through emotions—suspicion, calculation, something that might have been grudging respect.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: You speak like a man who understands the trap. This is... unexpected. From a Castilian. Both parties accept beforehand. The judgment is final. Ends the conflict. These are fine words. But words are wind, as we say in Genoa.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: I will tell you my problem, King of Castile. If I accept your judgment and the Venetian walks free—even if your reasoning is sound, even if the evidence truly absolves him—the Fieschi family will not accept it. They will say I was weak. exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: But. If I refuse, what then? The conflict festers. Trade suffers. Genoa and Venice bleed each other in the streets while the Ottomans sharpen their swords. And the Emperor—useless as he is—may expel us both. Or try to.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: So. I am prepared to consider your offer. But I need something more than your word that you will be just. I need to know how you will judge. What evidence will you examine? exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let me first tell you more about what is at stake here. I am about to give the people of Constantinople a choice. exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lomellini listened. His expression shifted as Juan spoke—the hard suspicion softening into something else. Not trust. Not yet. But attention. The attention of a merchant who has just heard numbers that change his calculations.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: Latins owning property throughout the city. A commercial court without corrupt judges. Trade exploding. You paint a pretty picture, King of Castile.
