If what you describe is real... if there is truly a new order coming... Then yes. Resolving this matter becomes more than blood for blood. It becomes—a foundation. Proof that the new way can work.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: But I am a practical man, Your Majesty. I have learned not to trust visions. Visions fade. Interests remain. What does Genoa gain from this new Constantinople? Specifically. Not promises of trade—everyone promises trade. What do we gain that Venice does not? Why should I risk the Fieschi family's wrath for a future that may never come?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Why wont you come to my palace tonight? The Venetian representative is coming as well. Let us together with the other Byzantines who want a future draft this future together. That is after all why we choose to cooperate. Because together we achieve more than alone and through violence. And let me reiterate, this will be a cooperation of equal opportunity. No corruption and no favoritism. The system does not discriminate. If Genoa seeks advantage, they should seek it outside this system. Trade better, work harder, sail faster. The system will then reward those who do.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: The Venetian representative. Contarini. At the same table. You ask me to sit across from the man whose people shelter Fieschi's murderer. To draft a future together, as if we were friends. As if there were no blood between us. Do you understand what you ask?

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: If I go to your palace tonight, word will spread. By morning, every Genoese in this quarter will know their podestà broke bread with Venetians while Fieschi lies unavenged. The Fieschi family will hear of it within the week. They will say Lomellini has gone soft. That he has been bought by a Castilian king and Venetian gold.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: And yet. If I do not go, and this new order you speak of comes to pass... Genoa is not at the table. Venice shapes the future while we sulk behind our walls. I have seen what happens to those who refuse to adapt. They become irrelevant. Then they become poor. Then they become nothing.

exchanges.speaker: raffaele_lomellini
exchanges.text: I will come tonight, King of Castile. But I will not pretend friendship with Contarini. I will not smile and clasp hands while my merchant's blood cries out. And I will need something to show my people. Some sign that Genoa's grievance is heard. That this... cooperation... does not mean surrender. Can you give me that?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: I do not expect nor demand kinship between the two cities. But I do hope that common interests wins, that we can see that by not resorting to violence, we have much to gain. That through true justice, trade flourishes. Let tonight be of common interest. I thank you for your trust. Until tonight.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Lomellini inclined his head—not a bow, but an acknowledgment. The closest thing to respect a Genoese podestà would offer a foreign king under these circumstances.

Despite skepticism from Podestà Lomellini about Venetian influence and the Fieschi family's demands for blood vengeance, Juan convinces him to attend a joint meeting by promising a reformed commercial system that would benefit all Latin quarters equally through lawful trade rather than violence.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: The great hall had been prepared. Not the intimate cabinet chamber where councils had fractured and reformed—something larger. A long table. Candles and oil lamps casting warm light against Byzantine frescoes. Wine and food laid out, though Juan suspected little would be eaten.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Captain Fernán arrived first, with Sotomayor and García. They positioned themselves around the room—not sitting, but present. Watching.

exchanges.speaker: fernan_alonso_de_robles
exchanges.text: The Queen and Princess are secure on the flagship. The harbor gate remains in our hands. No movement from Notaras's men since this afternoon.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Finding the twelve proved more difficult than Juan had hoped. The men he sent returned with only three: the wall worker, whose name was Theodoros; the young firebrand, called Demetrios; and—unexpectedly—the merchant's wife, whose name was Anna.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: The others were afraid. When your men came asking, they thought... they worried it was a trap. That Notaras had sent men dressed as Castilians.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: I told them they were cowards. That the Latin king had shaken our hands and promised protection.

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: I came because my husband forbade me to. Sometimes that is reason enough.

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Kantakouzenos arrived as the sun set, still in military dress, his scarred face unreadable. He surveyed the room—the Castilian knights, the three commoners looking lost among the finery—and raised an eyebrow but said nothing.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: You invited them?

exchanges.speaker: lomellini
exchanges.text: Bailo.

exchanges.speaker: contarini

exchanges.text: Men and women of the city. We are gathered here to set to paper that will define the destiny of the city and christianity in the east. exchanges.text: A gradual approach. Build trust before testing it. This could work. If managed carefully.

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: Let us first set the rules and let them race separately. It will be done. And my men will be working on restoring other parts of the city as well. Not just the walls, the hippodrome, but the aqueducts as well. Now, lets go to another part of what fighting for the city would include. It would include a pact that everyone fights. Not everyone with swords in their hands, but with what they can contribute. Monks pray and care for the wounded, traders provide supplies and pay taxes. And nobles provide their men and themselves to the crown in this fight. No one can hide anymore behind old privilege. We all fight and we all contribute. How will the Byzantines feel about this principle?

exchanges.speaker: kantakouzenos
exchanges.text: How will the Byzantines feel? The common people will cheer. The nobles will howl. For years I have begged—begged—for the great families to contribute their household guards to the defense. Do you know what I receive? Excuses. Delays. Promises that vanish like morning mist. Notaras alone commands three hundred armed men. Three hundred! Sitting in his warehouses, protecting his gold, while I scrape together enough bodies to man the walls.

exchanges.speaker: theodoros
exchanges.text: We know. We have always known. We dig, we carry, we stand watch in the cold. And we see the great lords pass by in their fine clothes, surrounded by guards who never lift a spear for the city. If your law forces them to fight beside us—truly fight—then yes, the people will support it. Gladly.

exchanges.speaker: demetrios
exchanges.text: It is justice. Finally, justice. Why should a man with gold be worth more than a man with calluses? Why should his sons live while ours die?

exchanges.speaker: anna
exchanges.text: Every mother knows this unfairness. We send our husbands, our sons. The rich send nothing. If you change this, the women will bless your name.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: A moment. The principle is sound. But the Church... how does this apply to monasteries? To clergy? You said monks pray and tend wounded. But some will ask—is this enough? Will there be... quotas? Requirements?

exchanges.speaker: juan_ii
exchanges.text: A requirement that all must contribute within their means. In the case of the church, this means helping when called upon. And taxes as well. One tenth to the crown, would this be fair?

exchanges.speaker: narrator
exchanges.text: Father Gennadios was silent for a long moment. His ink-stained fingers tapped slowly on the table. The scholar's mind working through implications.

exchanges.speaker: father_gennadios
exchanges.text: One tenth. A tithe to the crown. From the Church. Your Majesty, I must be frank. What you propose is... unprecedented. The Orthodox Church has never paid secular taxation. Our monasteries, our lands, our holdings—these are consecrated to God. To tax them is to tax God Himself. I do not say this to refuse. I say it so you understand the weight of what you ask. The Patriarch will call this sacrilege. He will say you seek to make the Church a servant of the crown. He will preach against it from every pulpit in the city. And many will listen. The monasteries are beloved. They feed the poor. They shelter the sick. If the people believe you are robbing God's houses... But. But I am not blind. The monasteries hold wealth while the walls crumble. Some abbots live like princes while soldiers starve. This is not what Christ intended. This is not holiness—it is hoarding. If you frame this correctly—if the tithe goes visibly to defense, to the survival of Christian Constantinople—some clergy will accept it. The younger priests. The ones who see what I see. But you will need to offer something in return. Some guarantee of Church autonomy. Some promise that this is taxation, not domination. What assurances can you give?

encounters.recap: Juan presents his conditions for defending Constantinople: Latin settlement rights, universal civic obligation including noble military service, and Church taxation at one-tenth. The three Byzantine commoners support Latin integration and noble obligations as matters of survival and justice. Venetian and Genoese merchants cautiously agree to separate racing competitions. Father Gennadios warns that Church taxation will face fierce resistance from the Patriarch but acknowledges some clergy may support reform for the city's survival.
